summaryOfNewsArticle: The Louvre Museum in Paris was targeted in a brazen heist on Sunday morning, when four thieves used a mechanical lift and power tools to break into the Galerie d'Apollon via a balcony near the River Seine. They calmly entered, threatened guards, and stole eight 19th-century royal jewellery items including diadems, necklaces, and brooches, which are considered priceless and of immense historical value. The thieves escaped on two scooters, and two items were reportedly dropped near the scene. No injuries occurred, and authorities say the heist was executed professionally and swiftly, lasting only minutes. The incident is part of a recent surge of museum thefts in France, including prior thefts at the Cognacq-Jay and Hieron Museums. Investigators are analyzing CCTV footage to identify the suspects. The event underscores the need for improved museum security in light of past high-profile thefts, such as the 1998 disappearance of Le Chemin de Sevres and the 1911 theft of the Mona Lisa.
